Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Galaxy Evolution in the Cosmic Web: RESOLVEing the Missing and Invisible
Award.AbstractNarration:
Dr. Kannappan proposes to lead and carry out a project that will advance our understanding of cosmology by investigating the 'missing baryons' problem, so named since most of the normal baryonic matter predicted from early-universe cosmology is not seen at the present epoch. She will investigate this problem by conducting the RESOLVE (Resolved Spectroscopy Of a Local VolumE) survey. RESOLVE will produce 2-D optical and radio spectroscopy of a carefully selected sample of approximately 1500 galaxies in the nearby cosmic web. When the survey is completed it will be the first to:

- Directly determine the fundamental distribution of internal velocities within the sample, i.e. the 'velocity function' of the sample
- Perform an analysis of disk growth and survival in relation to merging and cosmic structure
- Put a new type of constraint on the distribution of missing baryons through a self-consistent mass census which will be analyzed in conjunction with star formation patterns and numerical simulations

Dr. Kannappan will use the data from RESOLVE to train a new generation of scientists in multiple areas of astronomy including: spectroscopy, radio astronomy, and survey data handling. RESOLVE data will be made available on the web where it will be used in data-driven activities that are geared toward projects for high school and undergraduate students. Additionally, Dr. Kannappan will develop an astronomy curriculum that is aligned to the North Carolina science standards. This work is in collaboration with current teachers and is based on her experience in the Teach for America program, a program that typically targets minority and/or low-income communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vast dynamic range of the Universe rarely allows researchers to fully understand the properties of the very small – dwarf galaxies – in relation to the very big – the arrangement of galaxies into a huge “cosmic web” of filaments, walls, groups/clusters, and voids. To meet this challenge, the PI, colleagues, and students launched the RESOLVE (REsolved Spectroscopy Of a Local VolumE) survey as well as its 10x larger companion ECO (Environmental COntext) catalog. Together, these data sets aim to provide an unprecedented integrated view of stars, gas, and dark matter in a census of galaxies spanning two large volumes of the cosmic web.

Stressing uniformity, completeness, and multi-wavelength understanding, the team pursued new observations ranging from ultraviolet imaging (measuring star formation rates) to radio spectroscopy (measuring gas reservoirs, the fuel for star formation) and optical spectroscopy (measuring internal chemistry and orbital motions tracing mass). In addition, archival optical and infrared data were reprocessed to provide superior estimates of the stellar content and structure of galaxies. Working closely with theorists, the team calibrated optimized metrics of galaxy environments, such as distances to neighboring galaxies and groups of galaxies, masses of dark matter “halos” around groups and clusters, and classifications of larger filament and wall structures.

Intellectual Merit

Using these data, the RESOLVE/ECO team has published several major results. An early result drawing on preliminary data showed that gas-dominated dwarf galaxies are rapidly doubling their mass in stars on cosmologically short timescales, contrary to the expectation that such galaxies have abundant gas due to feeble star formation. This result pointed to the necessity of large-scale cosmic gas inflows fueling galaxies. A subsequent ECO analysis of the demographics of galaxy disks (which form by gas inflows and star formation, as opposed to rounder “spheroid” structures that form when galaxies merge) revealed that environment strongly correlates with disk/spheroid structure and evidence of growing disks (young stars, abundant gas). The same small group masses (small dark matter halo masses) that favor gas-dominated dwarfs also turned out to favor disk growth, notably even disk regrowth around spheroids. Once again the data pointed to cosmic gas inflows, this time implicating theoretically predicted key group halo mass scales regulating such flows.

Highlighting RESOLVE's core science, our next results explored these key group halo mass scales in relation to the mass census of galaxies, which has puzzled the community for decades with its deficit of dwarf galaxies relative to expectations from dark matter theories. For the first time, RESOLVE enabled a census of the combined gas and stellar mass of galaxies as a function of group environment. The results were stunning: the seemingly simple overall galaxy mass census had been hiding great diversity in the galaxy mass census as broken down by environment. This diversity points to the destruction or disruption of dwarf galaxies in exactly the intermediate-mass group environments where the group dark matter mass has begun to limit efficient cosmic gas inflows, thus linking the puzzle of deficient dwarf galaxies to the growth of galaxy groups. In another study, we examined the dependence of galaxy gas richness on environment more thoroughly, finding evidence that group mass is just one of several environment variables influencing gas content. Larger-scale cosmic web density, and similarly the proximity of dark matter halos to other halos, also determine gas content.

These results of RESOLVE and ECO have been exciting, and the surveys have much more to offer. Follow-up studies still to come involve optical spectroscopy we are still collecting, such as analyses of the internal velocities and metallicities of galaxies, as well as new directions, such as radio interferometry to map the gas in RESOLVE galaxies.

Broader Impacts

To provide a new discovery space for not only science but also education and exploration, the RESOLVE/ECO team worked with the Renaissance Computing Institute to create a dedicated searchable online database where all survey data is publicly released upon publication (http://resolve.astro.unc.edu/pages/database.php). Pursuing a key goal of the program, the team worked to integrate astronomical research into student learning from high school to college levels, for example organizing the one-week SMART (Summer Mentorship and Research Training) workshop for high school teachers and students (with supporting “AIMs” teacher materials at http://resolve.astro.unc.edu/pages/outreach.php) and more recently developing a new computational “galaxy astrostatistics” course for advanced students (made public at https://github.com/galastrostats/general/wiki/Syllabus). Through summer and term-time research experiences for undergraduates, nearly 30 undergraduates and one high school student have worked directly on projects with the RESOLVE/ECO team. The surveys also have trained six graduate students to MA or PhD level along with two postdoctoral scholars (one now in a faculty position). Everyone on the RESOLVE/ECO team from the PI to the undergraduates has interacted with the public at science fairs, museums, amateur events, and/or schools.
